As a theorem prover, Isabelle is not equipped to handle problems involving graphical figures directly. However, you can model the problem using sets and count the number of squares. Here's a possible encoding:

datatype Square = Sq1 | Sq2 | Sq3 | Sq4 | Sq5 | Sq6 | Sq7 | Sq8 | Sq9 | Sq10 | Sq11 | Sq12 | Sq13 | Sq14 | Sq15 | Sq16 | Sq17 | Sq18 | Sq19 | Sq20 | Sq21 | Sq22 | Sq23 | Sq24 | Sq25 | Sq26 | Sq27 | Sq28 | Sq29 | Sq30 | Sq31 | Sq32 | Sq33 | Sq34 | Sq35 | Sq36 | Sq37 | Sq38

definition squares :: "Square set" where
"squares = {Sq1, Sq2, Sq3, Sq4, Sq5, Sq6, Sq7, Sq8, Sq9, Sq10, Sq11, Sq12, Sq13, Sq14, Sq15, Sq16, Sq17, Sq18, Sq19, Sq20, Sq21, Sq22, Sq23, Sq24, Sq25, Sq26, Sq27, Sq28, Sq29, Sq30, Sq31, Sq32, Sq33, Sq34, Sq35, Sq36, Sq37, Sq38}"

by (simp add: squares_def)
